Verdict: An expansion of Portal’s core ideas that adds depth without sacrificing elegance.

Portal 2 builds on its predecessor by introducing more complex mechanics, stronger narrative elements, and cooperative play. The puzzles are more ambitious, yet remain readable and fair.

The writing and voice acting elevate the experience, giving personality to what could have been a purely mechanical game.

Final Thoughts:
Portal 2 proves that thoughtful iteration can enhance both gameplay and storytelling without diluting what made the original special.

A fantastically witty and charming puzzle game that improves on the original Portal in every way. The main story is top notch, and the multiplayer and test chamber creator make for hours of fun on their own.

With over 480 hours in Counter‑Strike 2, I can confidently say the game delivers one of the most polished and rewarding competitive FPS experiences available. The updated Source 2 engine provides smooth performance, crisp visuals, and responsive gunplay that stays consistent across every match. Utility, movement, and aim all feel precise, making improvement both measurable and satisfying.
Across my time played, CS2 has shown strong matchmaking balance, a healthy skill curve, and endless replay value. Whether grinding ranked, practicing mechanics, or playing casually with friends, the game offers a competitive environment that keeps you coming back. For anyone looking for a modern, skill‑based shooter with long‑term depth, CS2 is absolutely worth investing time into.

[h1][b][i]Diary of a PUBG unc[/i][/b][/h1]
The first time I played [i]PUBG: Battlegrounds[/i] was back when it was still called [i]PlayerUnknown’s Battlegrounds[/i]—[b]you had to pay back then to be a toxic ass.[/b] Despite it being PvP, not my favorite hobby, it grabbed me by the balls, its grip firm yet gentle, and from September 2017 till July 2018 I spent around 250 hours looting, sneaking, killing, dying (mostly dying) and sometimes eating chicken.

I still remember queuing up for my first solo, riding the plane, being mesmerized by the giant map, all the funny sounding names, and one stood out—[b]school[/b]. I thought, [i]“School? Who would want to revisit childhood random boner trauma, as it greeted you in the middle of algebra class, you just sitting there, praying to whoever is listening up there, that the teacher doesn’t pick you to come up front and explain to everyone what the author really meant when he wrote: [b]“In men there are two wolves.”[/b]I’ll go there, it’ll be empty for sure!”[/i]

It was in fact, not empty

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3652187216
[h3][b][i]Hoarder Sim[/i][/b][/h3]
Now, the main reason I even stepped foot onto Erangel, all those years ago, was [b]the looting.[/b] It’s just so zen, yet it’s also one giant [i]risk-reward[/i] game: deciding what to carry with you, what to drop, what to swap out—[b]I get all tingly from just thinking about it.[/b]

But what loot do you loot?
[list]
[*][b]Weapons:[/b]
You need to kill people, and melee-ing is so passé. So, bullets are the answer—[b]headshots[/b] or [b]spray and pray[/b], dealer’s choice. As years passed, the game’s arsenal expanded, which for a loot monke like me, seeing so many guns all around me, it’s basically better than the sex! My current favorites are the [i]AUG[/i], [i]SCAR-L, VSS[/i] and [i]M249[/i]. The [i]Crossbow[/i] also gets a thumbs up—[b]very hard to kill people with, much dying in chaotic gunfights because it’s pretty useless in 99.999% of situations I found myself in.[/b] Looks cool tho! Oh, there’s also grenades. [b]Pro Tip:[/b] do try and kill the enemy if you are using frags, m’kay?

[*][b]Attachments:[/b]
Think of guns like puzzles with a piece or two missing—[b]that’s the attachments, the missing piece(s)![/b]. These little doohickeys are very important, like little [b]gun buffs[/b] if you will. They can improve [b]stability, recoil, magazine size, add scopes, etc.[/b] Hot take—[b]pimping out your gun with attachments is more fun than winning[/b]—(can’t) change my mind!
[/list]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3652204471
[list]
[*][b]Consumables:[/b]
There’s many things to consume nowadays. Your favorite uncle consumes Fox News, you consume Hentai, and so on. In [i]PUBG[/i] you just kinda have first aid kits, bandages, etc. They heal the body and soul tho. But, there are exceptions—pills, [i](def not Monster)[/i] energy drinks, adrenaline shots, you can fill up on these and get a nice passive boost, pushing you past human limits. Why use first aid when you can heal by overdosing on pills and [i](not Monster)[/i] energy drinks? Plus, sounds cooler when the coroner reads your cause of death too.

[*][b]Gear:[/b]
Ok, so guns kill, attachments attach, and you consume consumables, what’s left? Well, I’m pretty naked right now, and don’t have deep pockets, so where all those [i](not Monster)[/i] energy drinks gonna go? What about ammo? Can my skull stop a Kar-98k bullet? Well, lucky for me, the map is littered with [b]helmets, vests, and backpacks[/b], all there to help my inner hoarder or protect me from other playerses nasty bulletses—[i]they want to steal my precious (loot)![/i] Gear come in three flavours, with Level 3 gear often found in hot zones or care packages dropped randomly during a match. Also, we now have a Jammer Pack. The standard [i]PUBG[/i] Jammer Pack does two things—[b]it’s a backpack and a jammer[/b]—stopping the nasty Blue Zone from hurting us… at least while its battery lasts that is.
[/list]

[h3][b][i]Two in the face, one in the ass’ base[/i][/b][/h3]
But you’re a man’s man’s man! You don’t play [i]PUBG[/i] to loot (I do tho), you play it to be the one who Chicken Dinners!

You have two options for dining, [b]Third Person[/b] and [b]First Person.[/b] Both allow [i]solo, duo and squads[/i]. And for those feeling extra masochistic, or just with big PP, you can drop [i]solo into duos/squads[/i] matches. I? Well, in the immortal words of Demi Lovato: [i]“I do it solo!”[/i]—[b]just me and my trusty right arm.[/b] But both duo and squads can be fun too!

Ok, so now we in: the plane is plane-ing and it's time to decide where to land. You’ll see many locations on the map, some with big names, some with smol names. [b]Big name = Big loot = Hot Zone.[/b] This is where I was taught the true essence of [i]PUBG[/i] combat—[b]don’t be a bitch![/b] I learned to loot faster, be more aggressive in gunfights, use my surroundings and audio cues to pinpoint players, and ofc, how to camp when enemies are all around me. In short, [b]hot zones[/b] are essential for your [i]PUBG[/i] growth, shaping men into slur-throwing boys—basically a [i]CoD[/i] lobby for the new generation: [i]“What?! How did he kill me? This ***** **** *** ***** ***** was clearly cheating! Report!”[/i] [b]—Average [i]PUBG[/i] enjoyer[/b]

Also, they have another [i]non-game[/i] related benefit that the penis doctor mafia doesn’t want you to know about—[b]landing in hot zones solved my ED.[/b] The surge of adrenaline, the blood pumping vigorously through [i]all[/i] the veins and arteries—[b]no magic pill can match it.[/b] So, next time, before laying down with [i]pillow-chan[/i], fire up a solo session and land in any hot zone, like [i]school[/i]—[b]you and the missus will thank me later.[/b]

And it’s when bullets start flying, and people start dying, [i]#rhyme[/i], that [i]PUBG[/i] turns into a fat lady and sings—it’s [i]perfection![/i] Even I, a loot monke, ended up loving the gunplay, despite sucking at it—[b]it’s just that damn addicting.[/b] Gunfights are a perfect showcase of your mastery of the game's mechanics and systems. Combat is not about who has the best or biggest gun—[i]brain[/i] beats [i]bullet[/i]! ... But [i]hack[/i] also sees [i]brain[/i] through the wall, 20km away, and can one-shot you, so…

In short, [i]PUBG[/i] gunfights are like getting ready for a date with that deSarmas girl from [i]Bladerunner[/i]. You pulled out all the stops, even bathed—[b]“Smell travels faster than light”[/b] —[i]Blindstein circa 2005 BC.[/i] You put on your best clothes, accentuating those love handles, so she knows you a good provider. And as soon as you step out, a Boeing 420 crash-lands on your head. It was an emergency landing, the pilot ate too much spicy Indian food and Boeing forgot to put toilets on their plane. You’re dead now and the toilet is clogged.

[h3][b][i]Chicken Winner[/i][/b][/h3]
But is [i]PUBG[/i] fun?

Well, let me tell you something you already know. [i]PUBG[/i] ain’t all sunshine and rainbows. It’s a very mean and nasty place, and I don’t care how skilled you are, it will send you back to the Lobby and keep you there permanently if you let it. You, me, or nobody is gonna hit as hard as [i]PUBG[/i]. But it ain’t about how many you kill. It’s about how many times you can die and keep playing. How many hacker headshots you can take and keep playing. That’s how [i]PUBG[/i]-ing is done!

In short, [i]PUBG[/i] fun.
I had fun.

This game doesn’t focus on horror as a main element, but if you run solo, do a dark raid, or enter a building with pitch-dark hallways, the atmosphere can switch very quickly. Because of how the lighting works, especially when combined with the flashlight, it can genuinely feel like a horror game.

If you find open doors or containers, that means another player has been there and that means you’re either hunting someone or being hunted. I’ve gotten some of my biggest jump scares from players hiding and waiting, then suddenly shooting me while I’m trying to locate them. This is especially true when you’re trying to stealthily make it to an extract and a rat player is waiting for you.

Stella Montis is a prime example, since most of the lights on that map don’t work and only a small portion of it is actually lit. The atmosphere in this game is insane. The gunplay reminds me of Battlefront (made by the same devs, by the way), and the world and technology give off strong Electric State vibes.

The gameplay loop is very satisfying, even when you lose everything. There is a battlepass but it’s called the Raider Deck, it’s completely free, and you can earn skins and cosmetics just by playing the game.

Ok its probably time to move away from this game...I will state that arc riders is a fine game...but at the core its a deeply flawed game with really unbalanced mechanics and pretty mediocre game loop and thats why i call this a 100 hour videogame...Even this will be focused on the critics you will get a good value proposition for 40 euros...and i think the price was intendent that way...I really like PVPVE design these days...it offers probably the most intensive and interesting gameplay from any kind of gengre of multiplayer games these days....
Played tarkov for almost 500h,hunt 2k now and various PVPVE games(cycle,marauders)and still hunt for new stuff.

Lets start with the good things...The game has probably the best use of UE5 engine to date...One of the best frame generation solutions that works and dont give a LOT of latency...For this the game runs even on a older HW and still looks good.Graphics and esthetics are outstanding,stylish punchy .Sounds and soundtrack are very immersive and give the game that 80s sci fi vibes that it needs...One of the best sounding games on the market...

And now for the bad part/s... I will try to make it as short as possible...
As from technological standpoint game really needs to fix the desync and server issues that are plaguing the game from beggining...Iam tired to see the orange an red netcode warning on my screen all the time....which are resulting in past corner shots and past delayed deaths...Its a mess to be engaged into pvp like this...
They really need to fix the cheating problem...it creates and moves players into passive play becouse of the behaviour matchmaking(more on this in my game design rant)

Now into the the gameloop and design itself...oh were to start...
Behaviour matchmaking sounds good on paper but in terms of a PVPVE game it turns game either into a pvp sweatfest in which you will encounter inly free loadout players or cheaters...or into a lootgoblin type of gameplay in which you run as quick as possible into high loot/card area and try to loot as quick as possible all the stuff and extract becouse you are in pacifistic lobbies...
PVE part and arc are only important for the quest/story since you need parts from them...AFter you finnish this portion of the game PVE and arcs doesnt provide you anything more than just xp and progression for the deck...
PVPVE games should not work on any kind logical preconditions at the start of the map.It really removes the intensity..The different spawns dont  work also...Its still better to just extract and restart to game until you get the good position to run quickest to the card related point on the map...Otherwise you are risking your gear or time...When you are out of high loot cards just craft power rod and go power rod room night raid runs...Night raids are the prime condition for high tier loot and maybe the harvester...so they are the most interesting...
Weapon balance also makes no sense..Why are the grey weapons so powerfull and with the attachment almost top level?Whats the point to craft the green ones?(probably only anvil makes sense)The whole weapon balacne needs to be scrammed and changed...How many mechanical components and springs do i need all the time?

The good: Graphics and maps are great, Gameplay mechanics are solid, finding and crafting better materials as you progress is satisfying, playing with friends is a blast, the ARC enemies are fun to go up against - though there needs to be more variety beyond "rolling balls of f*ckery" and "Amazon death drones".

The bad: A.I. voices for the characters. I can't, in good concience recommend a game that would replace real talent with generative A.I. EVEN IF actual VAs were used to train the A.I. tool used.

The Ugly: PvP is a mess in this game. On paper the idea is solid: scavanging in a post-apocalypse world, not knowing who to trust, possibly having to defend yourself in the event a player migtht be hostile. It adds a layer of anxiety and tension to every player encounter and that aspect I do like.

HOWEVER, the PvP in this game is just outright toxic and poor in execution. The devs said that PvP is NOT the main focus of the game - the main focus being scavenging, working together as a community, and fighting the ARC - yet so many players treat the game like PUBG/Fortnite and think camping at exits to cheap-shot non-PvP players makes them super MLG players (it doesn't, it just means you're a cowardly c**t who wouldn't last 10 seconds in an ACTUAL PvP game).

As a result, for non-PvP players, the desire to hop into a match to complete tasks, scavenge, and craft is borederline non-existent.

At the end of the day, Arc has a solid gameplay loop, good mechanics, good maps to explore, and enemies that provide a challenge without becoming a neusance. But it is held back by a poorly implemented PvP system (and a PvP community that is 95% toxic MLG wannabes), and the A.I. voices are still a major negative for me as well.

If you do get the game and wish to avoid PvP as much as possible, I recommend that you:

A) turn off crossplay. This lowers the chances of winding up in toxic PvP lobbies

B) Play solo matches.

If you want to play with friends, go for it as it is still fun. Though be prepared for a higher chance of PvP the more players you have in your party.

ARC Raiders is so brilliant and thoroughly detailed in both visuals and mechanics that makes the whole experience run smooth as honey-soaked silk if your PC specs are up to date. 

Overall in this genre, I'd say this game is unchallenged by everything I've tried the last 15 years or so. Last time I can remember feeling like this was perhaps when PUBG first released, though not with the frustration of rubberbanding myself through way worse graphics. 

Before trying it out, I had a few doubts after reading several posts about toxicity and aggressive PvP ruining the whole game for some people. I'm not a heavy PvP player myself, but the constant lingering uncertainty about every fellow raider you meet, and all the wacko encounters along the road just makes everything so much more intense and fun. It's not only the game you play, it's also the element of reading people, exploring your sense of moral and trusting your guts. If you get killled, so what? The constant thrill of loosing everything comes hand in hand with an intense feeling of relief when you make reach the safety hatch with your friends.

[h2]ARC Raiders understands what makes extraction games compelling—then removes the uncertainty that gives it meaning.[/h2]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]TL;DR – Core Claims[/h2]

- Extraction games are at their best when [b]player behavior is unpredictable[/b], driven by mixed goals, playstyles, and risk tolerance.
- ARC Raiders has strong foundations for this: [b]PvE creates objectives and exposure[/b], [b]PvP creates unknown threat[/b], and extraction choices and loot value create tension.
- [b]Aggression-based matchmaking undermines that tension[/b] by sorting players, by and large, into predictable PvE or PvP-only lobbies.
- This removes a core pillar of extraction gameplay: uncertainty about other players—their presence, their intent, and the consequences of being noticed.
- PvE lobbies become safe, repetitive loot-farming with little risk or long-term meaning.
- PvP lobbies strip away PvE objectives and context, leaving mechanically weak PvP compared to dedicated alternatives.
- The optimal way to progress on reset is to avoid PvP entirely, incentivizing [b]hoarding instead of meaningful risk-taking[/b].
- Over time, both PvE-focused and PvP-focused players are likely to leave for games that do those experiences better.
- What’s lost is the mixed highs and lows that only unpredictable triumph and failure can create.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Long Version (for "Better Than a Game Journalist" Magazine)[/h2]

Extraction games live and die by uncertainty. They work best when players enter a map with different goals, levels of investment, and tolerances for risk. PvE objectives pull players into vulnerable situations, while the possibility of other players—hostile, neutral, or unseen—creates tension. Preparation is mandatory; you’re rarely reacting to what is happening so much as what [i]might[/i] happen, and that tension is what makes both success and failure meaningful.

ARC Raiders understands this mechanically. PvE enemies aren’t meant to be lethal on their own; they create objectives, noise, and risk. Even tougher encounters become manageable with the right tools. The real danger is time, positioning, and whether another raider notices. Extraction choices—limited exits, timed extracts, night maps—reinforce this by making loot matter only if you escape.

[b]Aggression-based matchmaking undermines that loop.[/b]

By sorting players into mostly PvE- or PvP-focused lobbies, the game removes the uncertainty that gives these systems meaning. In PvE lobbies, player interference is akin to a cryptid sighting. In PvP lobbies, it’s constant and expected—fire a few shots, set off some flares, and you’ll have sharks circling in minutes. In both cases, the unknowns that drive tension are flattened.

The result is two diminished experiences. PvE lobbies become safe, repetitive loot runs against simple AI. PvP lobbies lose PvE context and objectives, leaving constant combat that struggles to compete with dedicated PvP games. Each half is outclassed by alternatives that fully commit to those roles.

This also encourages players to optimize the fun out of the game. On reset, the most efficient path is to avoid PvP entirely—complete quests, farm loot, and build wealth with minimal risk. Progression is faster, loss is rare, and hoarding replaces meaningful risk.

Over time, this predictability erodes replayability. PvE-focused players will seek richer, intentionally designed cooperative experiences—looter shooters, Monster Hunter–style games, and other PvE titles built around depth and variety. PvP-focused players will gravitate toward tighter, more rewarding combat elsewhere, whether that’s battle royales or PvP-first extraction games like Hunt: Showdown. What’s lost is the mixed space in between—the tense highs and lows that come from not knowing whether a decision ends in triumph or failure.

ARC Raiders has the foundations of a compelling extraction game, but aggression-based matchmaking cuts against the very uncertainty that gives the genre its edge.

Left the tutorial and launched my first raid. My quest was to find wires — I feel like quests should be a bit more compelling and offer some sort of substance beyond "collect 5 wires." I found wires after fending of some AI enemies. Cool. Guns feel good enough to use. Began walking to an extraction site and got instantaneously obliterated by two people ratting behind a wall eager to make a surprise kill. Launched a second raid with a buddy this time and we were exploring the map and fending off some AI. We found another team and shouted "don't shoot" because I had wires again; we were shot and killed on sight by mega sweats. I get it's a PvP game, but it isn't very satisfying to run around aimlessly looking for seemingly insignificant items like wires just to get ratted for no reason. What's the point? My goo-goo-gamer-monkey-brain needs something of substance beyond "find basic thing" and maybe die for no reason by an unemployed uber-eats premium member. I would be a bit more compelled to engage in a gameplay loop that allowed me the opportunity to get something decently powerful or dangerous to hold each time instead of broken wires. Getting shot and my only inventory items are wires and broken ARC parts just feels pointless and frustrating. Perhaps the extraction genre just isn't for me. I need a compelling narrative or PVP that rewards me for killing AI (to prepare for the inevitable PVP) and not punishing me for exploring the map and getting murdered by someone sweating, waiting, and just there to kill.

ARC Raiders Review – Incredible PvE, Ruined by Rats

ARC Raiders has serious potential. The PvE is actually the best part of the game — fighting ARCs, planning routes, deciding when to engage or extract — it’s tense in all the right ways. When you get to experience it, it’s great.

The problem is you almost never get the chance.

I can’t load into a match without being instantly killed by rat players camping spawns. Solo, duo, or trio — it doesn’t matter. The matchmaking is fair on paper (1v1, 2v2, 3v3), but that doesn’t help when the other side’s entire strategy is to sit on spawn points and farm kills before anyone can move.

This isn’t about getting outplayed in PvP. PvP is expected. The issue is that the PvE — which is clearly the heart of the game — is completely overshadowed by players who refuse to engage with it at all. I can’t raid, loot, knock down a big ARC, or even touch the Matriarch because most runs end in seconds.

The gameplay loop quickly becomes:
Spawn → die → reload → repeat → question life choices.

When the most efficient strategy is ignoring the game’s best content and griefing fresh spawns, something is broken. The game needs better spawn protection, smarter spawn placement, or a short grace period — anything that lets players actually play the PvE they queued for.

I really want ARC Raiders to succeed. The foundation is strong, and the PvE proves it. But if rat gameplay continues to dominate, it’s going to drive away players fast.

Verdict:
Excellent PvE. Solid PvP foundation.
Currently unplayable thanks to spawn-camping rats.

Verdict: A brutal survival game where player interaction—not systems alone—defines the experience.

Rust’s mechanics are deliberately unforgiving. Progression, base-building, and combat are tightly intertwined with social dynamics, making every encounter meaningful. Trust, deception, and power structures emerge organically rather than through scripted systems.

The game excels at emergent storytelling. No two wipes play out the same, and player-driven conflict creates moments that feel more intense than most scripted experiences. However, this same freedom can be overwhelming or frustrating, especially for solo players.

What Works Well

Emergent, player-driven gameplay

Deep base-building systems

High tension and stakes

Strong long-term replayability

What Needs Improvement

Extremely punishing for new players

Time investment can be excessive

Community behavior varies WILDLY

Final Thoughts:
Rust is not a comfortable game—but for players willing to embrace its harsh design philosophy, it offers unforgettable experiences and unattainable fantasies.

This game is Not for Ryzen 6000 series processors, I've been trying to play this game for 17hrs and still i couldn't play it tried to fix it but nothing happen. This game is unable to create a shader file in Documents and due to this its locking my FPS to 7 as Ryzen 6000 series processors runs on 2 types of cores i.e. P-core(performance core) , E-core( Efficiency core).

When I researched about it I've come to a realisation that its anti cheat is interfering with the processors by watching CPU threads movement across P/E cores(performance /Efficiency cores) and activates a fail safe that makes the game not save the shaders and drop and lock to 7 FPS

So basically, the root cause is the CPU scheduler conflict on Ryzen 7 6800H Laptops
-> fc 26 + anti cheat detects thread movement between P-cores and E-cores
->Anti-Cheat enters failsafe mode, locking FPS to ~7, even though GPU is fully used
-> windows tweaks , shader cache, or reinstall cannot fix the underlying scheduler conflict

GTA Enhanced is a game that, according to many people, could have at least changed for the better in some way after Legacy — which did not happen. According to *ockstar, a changed explosion effect, some minor tweaks to reflections, and a super-idiotic motion blur effect are, in their opinion, the update we deserved after about 20 changed accounts due to bans.

What I mean is this: I invested a huge amount of money into this game without any internal microtransactions, probably at three times the price GTA 6 will cost. Don’t judge me for playing with cheats, because in this game without them, first of all, it’s boring, and second, it’s impossible to play in a way where you don’t just play for a month and then forget about it.

A huge problem they simply do not want to pay attention to right now is that stupid updates — even the smallest ones — are worse than what they used to release back in 2019–2023.

I also forgot to add: why did you add an anti-cheat that, first of all, does not help against cheaters at all? It only prevents them from staying in a session for too long before the anti-cheat finally smells something with its ass and kicks the cheater. In that time, a cheater can just crash everyone or spend 10 minutes bullying the entire session. Either drop this anti-cheat idea entirely and let normal cheaters play so people can actually have fun. Not all cheaters use cheats to ruin the game for others — I personally fought other cheaters who were griefing, using my own cheats against them. Or actually finish the anti-cheat properly so cheats don’t work in the game at all, not even for 30 seconds.

And lastly, what are these 3 MB updates that add one livery to one car, for fuck’s sake? Are you mocking people? You are clearly showing that you don’t care about anyone, only about making money, and once a month you throw a spit in people’s faces in the form of an update that adds a livery which doesn’t look normal even under banned substances. ⭐ 10/10 | 600+ Hours on PC and still not done

After 600 hours on PC, I can confidently say: GTA V is not a game, it’s a lifestyle.

Story mode is absolute gold. Three protagonists, insane missions, solid humor, and a world that actually feels alive. Even after finishing the story, Los Santos keeps pulling you back in—random events, side missions, mods, replays… it never really ends.

GTA Online is pure chaos in the best way. Heists, businesses, races, PvP, co-op with friends, and yes—sometimes pure madness in public lobbies 😅. It can be grindy, but when you’re playing with friends or pulling off a clean heist, it’s unmatched.

On PC, the game shines even more:

Smooth performance

Better graphics & FPS

Mods that completely change the experience

Keyboard + mouse gunplay feels great

Is it perfect? No. Online can be toxic sometimes and loading screens test your patience. But honestly, the amount of content, freedom, and replay value you get is insane.

If a game can keep you hooked for 600 hours and still make you want to log in again—that says everything.

Highly recommended. Worth every rupee. 🎮🔥

I have 164 hours in this game. At this point GTA V is less a game and more a lifestyle choice.

The open world is still incredible — you can do missions, run businesses, grind money, customize cars, or completely forget your plans and spend an hour doing absolutely nothing productive. GTA Online has enough content to keep you busy for months if you enjoy progression, collecting vehicles, and optimizing everything.

That said, GTA Online will test your patience. The game explains almost nothing, throws 47 phone calls at you the moment you log in, and occasionally reminds you that griefers and modders exist. Some updates feel amazing, others feel like they were designed by an accountant.

Still, there’s a reason people keep coming back. No other game lets you casually rob a bank, buy a flying bike, manage a nightclub, and then argue with random players in a public lobby — all in one session.

If you like open-world chaos, long-term grinding, and can laugh at the nonsense instead of rage-quitting, GTA V is absolutely worth it. Just don’t expect peace. Ever.

If you are considering buying this game for the story mode, I would highly recommend doing so. GTA V offers an extremely well detailed and immersive map that you can sink endless hours into, that even still holds up today despite being over a decade old. The amount of attention to detail, within the map, the in-game media such as websites, movies, and shows, and story is insane. I have roughly a combined ~1500 hours on GTA V/Online and I still find little details that I had never seen before.

I am making this review more specifically for GTA Online. 
GTA Online has so, so many issues that you can't really blame just one thing that makes it unpleasant to play. 
For starters, Rockstar has made the Online so absurdly anti-consumer that it is comical. The economy for GTA Online is so broken, usually against the player. Cosmetics, guns, properties, and upgrades are so absurdly priced and inflated, like the Stun Gun, costs 375,000 dollars? Missions and activities give almost nothing, and even doing the literal best money making methods, such as complex hour-long heists, still require multiple hours of non-stop grinding just to afford one relatively useful/new vehicle, not even including upgrades, or other barriers like properties or property upgrades. Not to mention that a lot of missions are designed to literally bore the player, you're given the slowest van and are tasked with driving across the map, playing delivery driver. It makes playing the game feel like a chore instead of something to have fun in, you are just doing the same mind-numbing activities just to afford that newly released car or property. 
I understand that Rockstar needs some form of monetization for constantly updating the online, but it seems like Rockstar is intentionally and artificially hindering player progressions and mission quality just to push players to purchase Sharkcards, that give players in-game currency. But what is even worse than Sharkcards, is GTA+, GTA+ is the scummiest anti-consumer aspect of Online. GTA+ is a subscription service that literally pay-walls content and has FOMO aspects like in-game items only being available for a limited time through GTA+. It is so frustrating seeing something get leaked or teased just to realize its unobtainable without buying the subscription. Even QoL features are locked behind the subscription, not to mention that the game constantly advertises GTA+ in-game on your phone. 

Another extremely jarring and frustrating issue with GTA Online is how the community/player-base functions. Instead of getting on Online to play with other people, I find myself, and many others, to be in their own bubble in an invite only lobby just grinding or playing missions alone/with friends. There are multiple reasons for this, such as griefers for one, but the online just doesn't work well for playing missions with multiple people, despite for being a literal online game. Playing missions with others can be so broken it's infuriating, sometimes the mission won't let send an invite, sometimes the game will desync and boot everyone out, and even when you do complete a mission, most of the time it'll just put everyone into different sessions just for you to have to load back into the clouds just to be in the same session. Rockstar won't even bother to fix these because they are too busy patching cosmetic exploits that don't even hurt the game (Rockstar blacklisting content is a whole separate issue)... Because of these issues people just don't even bother doing their missions or heists with multiple people, why go through all of that trouble when you can grind by yourself? Remember this is an Online game.

Even if you are willing to put up with these issues good luck trying to make new friends/communicate on this game, with the removal of text chat you can't even talk to people without texting them one at a time through the phone, why? If the developers are so incompetent that they have to nuke a feature because of links being spammed, a solvable issue, then the game never stood a chance. Why go into public lobbies if everyone is a mute and can't communicate? Why play with randoms on an heist if you can't make a plan? Even if you want to just do some fun adversary/PvP modes good luck matchmaking, as the 'quick-join' 90% of the time just doesn't even work, so no one even bothers trying to play them at all. All of these issues causes everyone who just wants to make money stay away from public lobbies, so now your left with lobbies that are just a playground for griefers and modders, making the situation even worse. Also I find it amusing how the game now requires BattlEye, yet modders are still apparent and can make your game unplayable and can potentially get you suspended/banned, how fun. 

I would only recommend playing GTA Online if you don't mind putting up with a grind, and if you have a group of friends who are willing to play. A lot of the content is locked behind having multiple people, so you need to have people who you can communicate with and are willing to put up with the game's server/sync issues. With the right people GTA Online can be an absolute blast, messing around in free-mode, doing big heists with friends, community game-modes... just avoid public lobbies unless you are willing to enter a giant war with the occasional modder who nukes the lobby and can get you banned.

Rockstar has decided to take an anti-Linux stance and render this game unplayable on multiplayer. For whatever reason they have made the decision that they value privacy stripping practices and invasive programming so much that they took away devoted players' access to their favorite part of the game. But, I suppose they got their money from all of us and that is all they care about. 

They games are good, the stories are evocative. The companies view on player freedom and privacy? Alienating. I can't support this company or recommend their products until they change their stance.

Geometry Dash is a rhythm-based platformer that has captivated players with its challenging levels and vibrant aesthetics since its release. The game is not just about jumping and flying through danger in a geometrical world; it’s also about timing, precision, and patience. Each level is meticulously designed to match the rhythm of the background music, creating an immersive and challenging experience. Players can progress through the levels in the main game, but there's also a vast array of user-generated content thanks to the level editor, which has created a thriving community around the game. Apart from the gameplay, Geometry Dash allows players to customize their cube with different colors and skins obtained through achievements or purchased in the shop. These customization options add a personal touch to the gameplay, giving players a sense of ownership over their progress and style.

If you aren’t already a fan of D&D or turn-based combat, this game may not be your cup of tea. Personally, that side of it never really clicked with me. I’m not into turn-based games, and if I were playing solo, this would’ve been a hard no. I only stuck with it because I was playing with a good friend group.

The major downside: a significant amount of my total playtime has been replaying the same content due to bugs. Early on we were using mods, which may have contributed—but it’s worth noting that one player in our group ran the exact same mods and completed the entire game without issue. Despite that, multiple saves were corrupted or broken. Around Act 1 we removed all mods entirely just to preserve progress. Upon searching for resolutions to these issues, I find that there are thousands of other posts about this- and they're years old. This stuff should have been fixed, and its clear now that it never will be. 

Act 2 was mostly stable, although we did encounter issues, it wasn't as bad, but once we hit Act 3, the wheels came off again. Right at the start of Act 3 we encountered a game-breaking roadblock that forced us to replay from an older save again. A few hours later, we hit another game-breaking issue and lost even more progress.

The actual gameplay, at its core, is good. The story is entertaining, and the ability to make choices and see different reactions from characters is genuinely well done. I went in completely blind, rolled a random character, and just committed to it—and I loved that part. It’s easily the least likely build I would’ve chosen on purpose, yet it led to some of the best moments we’ve had. That said, all of that good content is viciously undermined by the sheer volume of bugs.

For a $60 Triple-A game from a big name studio, the amount of serious bugs is honestly shocking. Steam’s two-hour refund window means you won’t discover these issues until it’s far too late to get your money back.

I don’t usually write reviews, but when a game lets you use “Speak with Animals” just to get roasted by a squirrel, it deserves this.
This isn’t just a game—it’s a 500+ hour (at least) invitation to a whole new world, with characters you’ll quickly grow attached to. The voice acting is on another level entirely, and the storytelling is some of the grandest out there. It truly shows that games need to be made with love, by people who would love to play them.
You see this love in the smallest details: the unique, despairing dialogue from a boss if you kill all his minions first, the way your class or race opens up secret conversation paths, or the fact that you can actually use a spell like 'Speak with Dead' on virtually every corpse you find, each with bespoke and often chilling lines.
This is why I really think that every fantasy lover should give BG3 a try. For even with all its flaws, it'll be marked in your mind, just as it was in mine.

I had to give up on this game. It's so disappointing to say that it just doesn't click for me. I loved DOS:II and when I learned that the same studio was making a licensed D&D game with the 5e rules that I had been using in my home games for years, I was ecstatic.

I stayed away from spoilers and waited for the full release of the game, but when it finally came out I wasn't impressed. What works in 5e often works because of the looseness with how rules are enforced at the table. What doesn't work in 5e is really brought to light when you have to interface with it in such an impersonal way. And what changed from 5e is usually for the better, but I also often find it puzzling. While there are many examples, one that hurts the most for me is how they gutted mage hand. In 5e, it's practically minor telekinesis (which was a thing in DOS:II that all characters could easily access), but in BG3 it's a once-per-day summon with massively reduced utility because of its cost to use. Again and again I find what excited me about playing a D&D game had been limited or removed entirely and replaced with systems that felt better suited for a different game license.

I have tried and tried and tried to enjoy BG3, but I can't even get through act 1 without feeling like it's a shadow of what it could have been. Which also makes me feel crazy considering how much everyone else loves it! How can I not recommend one of the greatest games in years that bucks the trends so many other studios have followed out of greed?

I so badly wanted to love BG3 as much as I did DOS:II. Hopefully the next game from Larian can do that, because I've given this one enough chances. Similarly, I've stopped playing D&D in favor of other RPG systems (Draw Steel, primarily), and so the original draw of 5e rules has nearly become a deterrent.

I'm not recommending, but it's not just because it didn't meet my expectations. I'm not recommending because I don't think that the gameplay is fun. I think looting bodies hurts the pacing of exploration. I think abilities feel too clunky to use. I hate casting mage armor and a bunch of ritual spells every time I rest, when tabletop D&D would resolve that with "I spend some time casting my buffs after every long rest" and never bringing it up again. Any damage from accidently pathing through hazardous terrain is a slap in the face when any DM would assume you take a safer route when it's easily available or let you know that you have to walk through fire if you go that way. I have to stop here because my list of gripes would go on forever and I would accomplish nothing but making myself angrier by thinking about this game any longer.

Dead by Daylight, this game was a unique breath of fresh air with its dark game of tag that had me interested since starting in 2019 as primarily a solo queue player. It has been several years since and this game has had ups and downs since that time, but I did what I could to enjoy the time on it whenever I did play.

This review is a warning to anyone who is thinking about playing this game alone. If you have depression, rage issues, or lacking self worth, then completely ignore everything and buy the game immediately because this could really scratch that itch if you have that addictive tendency to games like that.

Perks, are you a theory crafter? That's good, this game has a ton of perks in it to try new things for you. However, more than half of them will be unusable for you due to various gameplay/teamplay aspects that will rut your build useless in most cases.

Gameplay, I'll speak for survivors only here, sorry fresh killer mains. Once you load in, your match is going to be decided by a few factors. The first is the map you spawn into, the second is the RNG MMR you were given, is it a baby Pig player learning the game like you are? Or is it going to be a Ghoul/Krasue player who has every unenjoyable perk and addon equipped with 8,000 hours and a deep desire to see you uninstall by force tunneling you out of the game? Ohh goodie, surprises! You can tell the priority for quality gameplay matches isn't there because match lobbies pop in under 5 seconds these days. Nobody is the same skill level and it is all variable.

Do you like the cosmetics? Good, you will be spending years to obtain a handful of them unless you pay up front. Earning your cosmetics, DLC and other things in this game is a massive time sink. You can easily complete tons of other game series, MMOs and other content before you collect all the perks and DLC in here at the rate that they come out currently, be wary as this would require over 1,000+ hours of gameplay to get through.

Surely, the community buffers any of this does it? Yes and no, there are some good eggs in here still I'm sure, but the ratio of negative and otherwise bad experiences of people throwing a fit has gone from what felt like 20% of matches before 2020 all the way up to 70-80% of matches in the current day. This translates to about 4 of your 5 matches being matched with people who do an assortment of [Sweat, DC, Troll, Flame, Act entitled] among several other things. There came a point where Dead by Daylight wasn't as popular as it is now and with that popularity I'm sure Behavior has had one hell of a time trying to contain the kind of people this genre will attract.

As for the company themselves, I cannot add much of a comment here as I'm sure they take enough heat as is. I do genuinely believe that this game is very overdue for a competitor in order to push the company to proactively fix a large plethora of in game bugs, issues and overall community concerns.

Wrapping this up, Dead by Daylight is simply not a good experience in these recent years if you are a solo player who can see themselves going more than 100 hours deep into the game, I can only advise you take a look at the game's health in a few years and make your decision then. I will personally still be playing out of sunk cost fallacy alone, but if I could reverse the hours down to 500 or less, I would.

Extra Info for insight: I gave this game a break, I even play it casually, I do my dailies at times, and attempts have been made to "keep things fresh". It is still a miserable experience the moment killers/survivors misbehave over the dumbest things. League of Legends solo queue ranked has harbored less toxicity than what I witness here these days. Plenty of people I've met in Dead by Daylight also have mentioned it being terrible, they just get by and tolerate it. I didn't outgrow this game, the core gameplay loop itself is still there, but it is plagued by too many negatives to continue to give it the time of day anymore.

Anyways, hope this adds another stroke of paint to the picture this experience might be like if you decide to give it a go now or not. Best of luck to any journey you decide on regardless, take care.

My review as a survivor main:
I kinda love and hate this game at the same time. It is sometimes so unfair and hard, so you think about uninstalling it for good. But then you get a few matches, where you have so much fun and do so good, you will play again the next day. It's always luring in the back of your head, manipulating you to come back.

But honestly the fun starts (as survivor), when you really understand the perks of both sides, the killer powers and how to outplay them, to loop the different tiles and how to mindgame them, the management inside the team what to prioritise, do flashlight saves and so on. It's even more fun to play it with friends cause playing alone can get really frustrating. I really like the variety of different playstyles the game gives you with the 280 different perks. You can focus on the generators, on looping, on healing, or do a meme build, and so on. You can play how you want and test what build fits you best or you have the most fun with. It keeps the game interesting for me.

There are for sure some bad sides of it. For example a lot of bugs, broken game mechanics, bad mmr (you get queued with a surv with 10 hours and a killer with 5000 hours) which makes it really hard and frustating to play the game. The community is very mixed but mostly negative minded I would say. When you play really good and clean as a surv, the killer gets hella mad and camps you, or humps or insults you in post game chat. Even though you play the game as intended. A lot of people don't realise it is still to some part skill based and you can't blame everything on the game itself. Sometimes you're just bad.

Even with all the controversy, I would still recommend it cause It's just such a fun game. You need to invest a lot of time. But the real fun starts with some game knowledge.

I have played DbD for a few years now. the events are okay. the extra costumes are fun if you can afford them because you will not get enough iridescent shards to get all the ones you want. There is NO MMR SYSTEM. They claim it exists, but you will see expert killer/survivor teams as a low-tier killer/survivor at random meaning you will either get 4-outed or massacred at random regardless of your playtime or skill (Behavior could easily combat this with release how their MMR system works but they will never do that because it does not exist). There are many beginner folies built in that have never been addressed, so as a new survivor player you will be:
1) vastly underequipped to face the massive amount of killers and their powers
2) have many things on the map that you have never been introduced to and will interact with without knowing you are wasting your (and your team's) time
3) will be faced with triple-digit perks that you have no idea what and how they function, nor how to get them, meaning you will be a detriment to your team
4) have no idea what looping is, how to chain it, and how to be a credit to your team as a runner

and as a killer you will
1) not understand looping from the start and get bullied by stuns and flashlights as you try to learn
2) not have a proper introduction to all the perks that are available and how to use them
3) be BM'd in-game and/or subtly insulted in endgame chat by the survivors for playing poorly

Call me bad at the game, IDC. I am an average killer and average survivor and it is a fundamental problem if average players are turned away due to lack of knowledge or lack of experience against a multi-year long playerbase that insults a player for not performing to their standards. I like DbD with friends because everything is better with friends, but this game will decline further if quality of life improvements are not instituted for newer players, anti-cheat if not actually paid for on a subscription basis (looking at you BHVR) and balancing on both sides is taken seriously

This game was fun when it first came out around 17-18. but during covid and especially now has become runaway and lost itself like many other games that try to remain for decades instead of just a few years. instead of releasing a sequel, much needed improvements and implementing changes that in the event players disliked enough of them they could return to the original game they loved, they decided to keep this game running and fund it entirely through microtransactions and excessive licensing from other horror IPs when originally, much of the draw was from their unique and original characters. it has turned into horror fortnite in all the worst ways; and when they don't renew licenses they simply pull characters and maps out of the game. the game was originally heavily skill based but has turned into youtube/twitch fodder and is now simply based upon a small portion of perks the game offers for survivors and killers, removing much of the replayability and causing it to go stale rapidly. Furthermore, if you haven't been playing consistantly or for at least a few years now, memorizing all the perks or even half of the perks and what they do is virtually impossible, curtailing discovery of what you may like, further bottlenecking the game to remain in stale metas. Survivors has been buffed to the point of removing the fear factor from the game, which is the enjoyment of the game, just about outright. Which is a shame because I feel the game is best enjoyed with friends. Playing with friends using anything short of an irl blindfold will result in short matches with devastating loses for even the best killers. As a killer the game is no longer fun as you're no longer the threat in the game, and you're usually going to deal with at least one person streaming the match which unless you yourself are a streamer, likely don't want every single match you play streamed whether you win them or lose them. The game was originally built around the idea survivors had to survive and struggle to do so, and the killers killed and fought to kill all of the survivors to win; and is now an all or nothing scenario for both sides. either everyone lives and its a full shutout or everyone dies in an absurdly fast match either way. like many good things these days, the game has sacrificed quality for quantity and vanished under the weight of its own mass production.
it isn't worth it on sale as it doesn't contain a lot of the free killers from console, and it definitely isn't worth it at full price. the game has been out for about ten years now and is still well over a hundred dollars just to play survivor or killer, let alone both. cosmetics are priced even higher than fortnite, and if you bought the game on console as well as cosmetics, they do not transfer to pc unlike fortnite.  The game also includes a battlepass, which is somewhat difficult to get full value out of even if you dedicate all of your time to just this game. If you have a job or go to school, the battlepass just isn't worth it.

These are my biggest issues with this game, and I'm leaving stuff out to not sound overly whiney:

1. Hit Registration in a shooter should be priority 1, and the hitreg in this game is terrible. You will have some games where you feel like you are shooting a laser beam and hitting everything, and other games where you will empty a clip in someone, all hits register on your screen, and they kill you and run away.

2. There is almost no bloom penalty for Jumping/Sliding and shooting, so the "meta" is to build a gun to be extremely accurate hip fire, and then jump/slide around the map causing lag and making you bounce around other peoples screens and killing them with pinpoint accuracy. If you aren't doing this, you are putting yourself at a disadvantage.

3. The main grind is weapon attachments, however the problem is the "good" ones...that make the guns actually usable....don't start unlocking until level 20 usually. For instance, a suppressor is pretty much required in this game to not be auto-spotted when you shoot your gun. Most don't unlock until level 20+, so you run around spotting yourself for the enemy team every time you fire your weapon. Most of the accuracy attachments that don't also come with penalties aren't available until later either. Couple this with an extremely slow XP grind for the weapons and it gets old fast.
Side Note: The xp boosters expire in real time. IE if you aren't in the game. If you are sitting in a queue. In a loading screen, etc. The booster timer is ticking down while you aren't even able to use it.

Bottom line, I would buy this at like $30 if I could get my money back. It is fun in some ways, but it is NOT worth $70. Especially if you have a hard time saying "no" to extra paid content because they push Season Passes and then they push shorter Battle Pass events all that you need to pay for to get all the content. And yes, there ARE weapons in these passes such as the Mini-Scout which is considered one of the best sniper rifles in the game right now.

As a battlefield 3, 4, Hardline, 1, and 5 veteran do not buy this game if you played and loved those. This game might be good for the COD type, but its not battlefield anymore. At times it feels like battlefield, at least on the surface. Once you play enough you will notice there are fuck ups in nearly every aspect of this game. Long story short the game is inconsistent. Here is a list of the inconsistencies; TTK (time to kill), hit detection, gun damage, the number of bullets it takes to drop someone, the number of bullets it takes to drop you, sometimes explosive splash damage hits the guy 2 ft away and sometimes it doesn't, and sometimes the match doesn't even give you all the xp and progress you made in a match.... I'm dead serious. This game is not a 1/10 by any means (I'm looking at you BF 2042), but holy shit they fucked up a lot of things. Things that previous battlefield titles had nailed down perfectly too. It is so confusing that they still have a lot of problems given the massive beta they had as well as previous games to utilize. The gunplay in bf6 feels alright, but needs a lot of work still. It feels too floaty and light to me. Maps needed more thought and planning put into their designs. Weapon balance is a joke, I hope you enjoy most other players running around with an assault rifle as their damage output is paramount. Either that or a wall of 6 snipers watch you spawn in. To give credit where credit is due the devs have made changes to the game according to the players wants, but that doesn't excuse all glaring issues. As a long time fan of the franchise it is hard for me to recommend this game to other long time fans. This game feels more akin to COD than battlefield. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but a bad thing for fans like myself imo.

The core gameplay is genuinely fun, but the experience is dragged down by an overwhelming number of bugs. The UI is clunky, menus frequently lock you in place, net code issues pop up at random, and the game crashes so often it feels unpredictable. At first, I assumed the problem was on my end, but after multiple attempts to troubleshoot to make sure it isn't solely on me, the issues continue to occur. With bugs as consistent as this, the game becomes borderline unplayable at times, which is unfortunate because I do enjoy the gameplay. 

Even setting the bugs aside, the map design falls incredibly short of Battlefield’s usual standards, and the progression system is severely slow. I regularly find myself saying "Oh great, its this map again", and despite having almost 100 hours of playtime, I still haven’t unlocked all the attachments for a single weapon. As for camos, that is out of the question, they are absolutely not worth the grind.
BF6 has a ton of potential, but it’s being held back by issues that shouldn’t exist at launch. Unfortunately, it feels like another victim of modern gaming problems at a corporate level. Half-baked/rushed release with many issues, and not enough updates to make it playable.

If you’re considering buying it, I’d strongly recommend waiting, because once the “honeymoon phase” wears off, the game gets incredibly frustrating to play.

226 hours
Oct 2025 release

Battlefield 6 is an ambitious entry that unfortunately struggles to justify its place in the franchise. While it attempts to modernize the Battlefield formula, the execution feels uneven and, at times, disconnected from what has historically made the series stand out.

The core gunplay lacks consistency. Weapon feedback and hit registration feel unreliable, which undermines confidence in firefights and makes engagements feel more frustrating than rewarding. Movement is serviceable but lacks the fluidity and weight expected from a modern shooter at this scale.

Map design is one of the game’s weakest elements. Several maps suffer from poor flow, offering either overly open spaces that punish infantry or congested areas that devolve into chaotic, unstructured combat. As a result, matches often feel random rather than tactical, diminishing the importance of positioning and teamwork.

Although environmental destruction is present, it rarely meaningfully impacts gameplay. Destruction appears more cosmetic than strategic, missing the opportunity to dynamically reshape encounters in a way that feels purposeful.

Vehicle balance is inconsistent. Some vehicles feel ineffective, while others dominate matches without sufficient counterplay, contributing to a sense that balance tuning is incomplete.

Ultimately, Battlefield 6 feels more like a transitional project than a confident evolution of the franchise. It delivers moments of spectacle but lacks cohesion, polish, and a clear identity. Longtime fans may find it difficult to recognize the Battlefield experience they expect, while new players may struggle to see what sets it apart from competing shooters.

The worst part, in my opinion, is the progression system. It’s locked behind a hard wall with overly long grind paths. There are already bot servers used for grinding. Starfield is a first and third person, roleplaying game, set in it's own sci-fi setting and pursuing what the developers call a "NASA punk" aesthetic.  As someone who played hundreds of hours of Bethesda's previous titles and a big sci-fi fan I was really looking forward to Starfield, bought it on day one. 

The space cowboys, pirates and Starborn powers in Starfield don't really mesh well with NASA realistic aesthetic (not that any of them are badly done, they just don't fit).

Graphics are higher resolution than Fallout 4, but not as good as Cyberpunk 2077.  Starfield doesn't have Fallout 4's classic music either.
Starfield suffers from frequent loading screens, feeling like far more often than necissary (this has been improved a bit since launch). 

Starship piloting and driving (which was added after lunch to get around the foot slogging across Starfield's many desolate planets and moons) are both new to Bethesda and janky.

Base building and crafting are crippled by the bewildering variety of resource types in Starfield.  I never seem to have the right combination of resources to do what I was trying with these systems or any one stop shops to get the resources I needed.

The user interface around moving inventory items from the player to and from containers, NPCs and ships is also janky.  Bethesda have been doing this for decades, I can't believe they messed up this very common part of CPRGs this badly.

I achieved the game's goal of reaching the Unity before writing this review, in the hope this would unlock some saving grace, but no... just more of the same jank.

In conclusion I do not recommend Starfield, it is a total disappointment.

Star Wars Outlaws is not a power fantasy — and that’s exactly why it works.

If you slow down, read the journal, listen to conversations, and play like a cautious scoundrel instead of a checklist-chasing hero, this game really opens up.

What surprised me most is how thoughtfully designed it is at a human scale. Quests are clear without being hand-holdy. Intel often comes from listening instead of icons. NPCs will sometimes call out to you rather than waiting to be clicked. You’re encouraged to weigh risk, reputation, and timing — not just rush in swinging a blaster.

The reputation system matters, stealth is situational (not puzzle-box perfect), and the world rewards restraint. You don’t have to do everything, and in fact, you shouldn’t. Ignoring opportunities that feel risky or inconvenient is often the smart, in-character choice — and the game supports that.

Exploration is clever too: speeder races and traversal help you learn the planet naturally, landmarks matter, and some jobs give directions instead of map pins, which keeps immersion intact if you resist the urge to waypoint everything.

It’s not flawless. NPC interaction depth is limited, and time-of-day transitions can feel abrupt if you linger and observe. But these are small seams in what is otherwise a surprisingly grounded and atmospheric Star Wars experience.

If you’ve ever wanted a Star Wars game that lets you exist in the galaxy rather than dominate it — one that respects patience, discretion, and moral restraint — this is absolutely worth your time. I strongly recommend it to players who enjoy slow-burn RPGs, immersive worlds, and thoughtful design. Give it a chance, play it deliberately, and it may surprise you as much as it did me.

If I had to describe this game quickly, it's Horizon Zero Dawn in the Star Wars Universe. Climbing puzzles, hiding in tall grass, which admittedly is out of place in some locations.  I am not far into the games story at the moment. I will however come back revise my review as I learn more about it. 

As I see it, this game has gotten a bad wrap. It is one of the better Ubisoft games, for me anyway. I bought it on a 70% off sale, and with a referral from my son saying it was actually good and fun. I concur with his brief review. lol, I am having fun.

Pro: 
It is a really nice game and I enjoyed it a lot. 
Nice storyline, nice open world not too much grind.
Nice mix of story, shooter, Tomb raider style jump around, and space battles.
Nice graphics.
Nice characters. 
Its is actually a solid ending for once both in dramaturgy and story. Many other games I played recently left me kinda in a "that is it?!?!" feeling

Nice vibrant world. Starwars theme is nice but not I'd say that the game would be equally good without it.... to extend that I was sometimes surprised to see R2-D2s standing around, and then remembered that this is in fact a Starwars game.  Also to the fact that Tatooine was the most empty planet. 


Con:

Bit buggy, crashes some times, you get the usual Ubisoft "cant activate the game" glitches so you cant play for 30 mins until they restart their activation servers.

Fights are unbalanced: Initially you need to sneak or get blasted immediately. Once the weapons are at a certain level you just blast 50 enemies down without ever dying. It was never the right amount of challenge.

I also thought the space battles were fun but got annoying very quickly. With the auto aim you really dont need to do anything. Just refresh the shields, get an enemy somewhere on the screen and the rest is automatic. Its one of those things where a controller first gameplay kinda ruins the fun. Wasted opportunity.

Respawn after saving or death made some longer missions quite annoying. If you have kids and need to run you end up playing the same mission effectively multiple times. It also makes you much more conscious about trying out new things / attacks / that cool new special you just learned. This took a bit fun out of the game / limits the play styles.

Overall the game has a lot of rough  edges. Cliffs and the open world does not fully match up. You sometimes get stuck in stone formations where you cant get out and need to reload. Calling your glider is kinda buggy or at least quite annoying. 

It is not always a huge world. E.g., Jabbas palace is not that big from the outside... and inside you got just a few hallways... just having Kay say every 2 minutes "this place is huge" is quite comical. Trying to hard

I just played Indiana Jones before -- just comparing it as it came out the same time and is from the same franchise -- and this game kind of what I hoped Indy would be. Indy is a much more bland world, 10x more buggy, weird controls, ... so I was quite happy to play this; never finished Indy sadly.

So, very entertaining game. Though, I think there is a quite a bit of lost opportunity to make it really cool. Is it in my all time top-10, probably not.

Bought the deluxe edition for 25 bucks on a 70% sale.
Played about 10 hours so far, might update the review later.
I would give it a 6/10 or 7/10 which is a pretty good score. 

Gameplay:
Overall, the movement of the character and driving feels pretty good.
The stealth is pretty good, along with your companion pet that has some abilities.
The takedowns are comedic.. not great. This skinny ass chick only throws haymakers lol..
Compared to for instance Ghost recon: Breakpoint, where the takedowns are brutal and amazing.. This game is not nearly on the same level. But i guess starwars has always been more goofy than brutal so i guess it is a design choice.
The climbing is ''Horizon zero dawn style.. which means it is limited and not that great.. but passable.
The grappling hook can only be used in designated locations, which is not great.. but passable.
There are a couple of ways to approach a mission, but they are limited due to the two points previously mentioned. Overall it sometimes feels like playing and old Tomb Raider game.

Graphics, sound and environment:
Overall, great world and worldbuilding.. very thematic. Music and sound is also great.
No complaints about the graphics.. except..
The main character looks a bit wonky. She is almost cute but not quite. Certainly not pretty. She looks a bit off.
Like a random character in a character creator, where you should adjust her features a little bit for her to look good, but you cant.
Other non human alien characters look quite good for the most part.

Story: So far seems alright. Maybe even good.

Wokeness: Female Han solo.. just because... right? 
(I usually prefer playing female characters so for me personally it is not a problem). 
Obviously the character look is a bit woke. She has no female shape really.. just skinny, which is still better than her being fat i suppose. 
Her face is wonky. Obviously that was a design choice.
Her ''personality'' and voice seems alright tho. I havent found anything over the top or immersion breaking so far.
Overall Quite a lot of female represantation in the game.
It is not nearly as bad as lets say Borderlands with the girlbossing. It is quite a good balance so far.
There are no hot women in the game at all. Not yet atleast..
Overall it is not like a fly in your eye while playing. It is quite okay, but there is no so called ''fanservice''.
Everyone in the universe is an ugly or average sob right? If ubisoft had a say in it Natalie Portman would never have had the role as princess Amidala.. the role would have been given to some 4/10 woman.

So anyway, I am thumbing it up for about 20 bucks.
I do not regret buing it, and it has been quite fun.
There are moments you feel the game is great, and then there are moments when you feel held back by the game mechanics.
Worth playing if you are into open world single player games and you wont be bothered by a few restrictive design choices.. or If you are into Starwars.
